clean_story: Decisions as branches.  Outcomes mapped like roots. "Game theory trees" borrow their name from how choices split like tree limbs—each branch a possible move, each twig an end result. Most see them as chess diagrams, but they’re closer to a choose-your-own-adventure book where every option has a cost. Start at the trunk: your first decision. Each branch forks into responses—like offering a deal or bluffing in poker. Leaves mark the payoffs: win $10, lose $5, or walk away empty. Here’s the precision:A poker tree might show "bet $20" leading to "opponent folds" (you win) or "opponent raises" (now you choose: call or fold). Real-world example?Auction houses use trees to predict bidder reactions before setting reserve prices. One quirk: "backward induction. "Start at the leaves, ask "What would I do here?", then work backward to prune irrational branches. Three related subjects are prisoner’s dilemma math, Nash equilibrium proofs, and how AI prunes decision trees.
